abstract.p: Newark Museum opens exhibit about wetlands wildlife featuring photos by Anne Heimann (S)

block.p: A barred owl in swampland at the Delaware Water Gap, ice-encased grasses in a New Jersey freshwater marsh, and a beaver in the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in Morris County are among images that explore the diversity of plant and animal life abundant in wetlands throughout the United States.
Photography, natural history and the environment are linked in an exhibition on wetlands on view at the Newark Museum through Sept. 17.

A barred owl in swampland at the Delaware Water Gap, ice-encased grasses in a New Jersey freshwater marsh, and a beaver in the Great Swamp National Wildlife Refuge in Morris County are among images that explore the diversity of plant and animal life abundant in wetlands throughout the United States.
Photography, natural history and the environment are linked in an exhibition on wetlands on view at the Newark Museum through Sept. 17.
The color photographs of Anne Heimann form the centerpiece of the show, which includes specimens from the Newark Museum's natural science collection.

The text accompanying the displays includes information on the importance of wetlands ecosystems and the threats facing the areas, which not only provide habitat for numerous plants and animals but also serve as flood control and a natural filtering system for water.
